questions.question: 18 mice were placed in two experimental groups and one control group, with all groups equally large. In how many ways can the mice be placed into three groups?
questions.solution:
Total mice = 18. Groups = 3 (Experimental 1, Experimental 2, Control).
Size of each group = $18/3 = 6$.
Number of ways to arrange them into 3 distinct groups = $\frac{18!}{6! 6! 6!} = \frac{18!}{(6!)^3}$.

questions.question: A bag contains six white marbles and five red marbles. Find the number of ways in which four marbles can be drawn from the bag if (a) they can be of any colour (b) two must be white and two red and (c) they must all be of the same colour.
questions.solution:
Total marbles = $6W + 5R = 11$. Draw 4.
(a) Any colour: ${}^{11}C_4 = \frac{11 \times 10 \times 9 \times 8}{24} = 330$.
(b) 2 White and 2 Red: ${}^6C_2 \times {}^5C_2 = 15 \times 10 = 150$.
(c) All same colour: (4W) or (4R).
${}^6C_4 + {}^5C_4 = 15 + 5 = 20$.

questions.question: In how many ways can a football team of 11 players be selected from 16 players? How many of them will (i) include 2 particular players? (ii) exclude 2 particular players?
questions.solution:
Total selection: ${}^{16}C_{11} = {}^{16}C_5 = \frac{16 \times 15 \times 14 \times 13 \times 12}{120} = 4368$.
(i) Include 2 particular players: Select remaining $11-2=9$ from $16-2=14$.
${}^{14}C_9 = {}^{14}C_5 = \frac{14 \times 13 \times 12 \times 11 \times 10}{120} = 2002$.
(ii) Exclude 2 particular players: Select 11 from $16-2=14$.
${}^{14}C_{11} = {}^{14}C_3 = \frac{14 \times 13 \times 12}{6} = 364$.

questions.question: A sports team of 11 students is to be constituted, choosing at least 5 from Class XI and atleast 5 from Class XII. If there are 20 students in each of these classes, in how many ways can the team be constituted?
questions.solution:
Class XI: 20, Class XII: 20. Select 11.
Constraints: At least 5 from each.
Possible cases (XI, XII):
1. (5, 6): ${}^{20}C_5 \times {}^{20}C_6$.
2. (6, 5): ${}^{20}C_6 \times {}^{20}C_5$.
Total ways = $2 \times {}^{20}C_5 \times {}^{20}C_6$.

questions.question: A group consists of 4 girls and 7 boys. In how many ways can a team of 5 members be selected if the team has (i) no girls (ii) at least one boy and one girl (iii) at least three girls.
questions.solution:
(i) No girls: Select 5 from 7 boys. ${}^7C_5 = 21$.
(ii) At least one boy and one girl: Total - (All Boys) - (All Girls).
Total = ${}^{11}C_5 = 462$. All Boys = 21. All Girls = 0 (need 5, have 4).
Ways = $462 - 21 = 441$.
(iii) At least 3 girls:
- 3G, 2B: ${}^4C_3 \times {}^7C_2 = 4 \times 21 = 84$.
- 4G, 1B: ${}^4C_4 \times {}^7C_1 = 1 \times 7 = 7$.
Total = $84 + 7 = 91$.

questions.question: If ${}^nP_r = 840$, ${}^nC_r = 35$, then $r = $ ______.
questions.solution:
We know that ${}^nP_r = {}^nC_r \times r!$.
$840 = 35 \times r! \implies r! = \frac{840}{35} = 24$.
Since $24 = 4!$, we have $r = 4$.

questions.question: The number of permutations of $n$ different objects, taken $r$ at a time, when repetitions are allowed, is ______.
questions.solution:
Each of the $r$ places can be filled in $n$ ways.
Total ways = $n \times n \times \dots \times n$ ($r$ times) = $n^r$.

questions.question: The number of different words that can be formed from the letters of the word INTERMEDIATE such that two vowels never come together is ______.
questions.solution:
Word: INTERMEDIATE (12 letters).
Vowels: I, E, E, I, A, E (6 vowels: 3 E, 2 I, 1 A).
Consonants: N, T, R, M, D, T (6 consonants: 2 T, 1 N, 1 R, 1 M, 1 D).
Arrange consonants first: $\frac{6!}{2!} = 360$.
This creates 7 gaps (_ C _ C _ C _ C _ C _ C _).
Select 6 gaps for vowels: ${}^7C_6 = 7$.
Arrange vowels in these gaps: $\frac{6!}{3! 2! 1!} = 60$.
Total ways = $360 \times 7 \times 60 = 151200$.

questions.question: Three balls are drawn from a bag containing 5 red, 4 white and 3 black balls. The number of ways in which this can be done if at least 2 are red is ______.
questions.solution:
Total balls = 12. Draw 3. Red = 5, Others = 7.
Case 1 (2 Red, 1 Other): ${}^5C_2 \times {}^7C_1 = 10 \times 7 = 70$.
Case 2 (3 Red): ${}^5C_3 = 10$.
Total ways = $70 + 10 = 80$.

questions.question: The number of six-digit numbers, all digits of which are odd is ______.
questions.solution:
Odd digits: 1, 3, 5, 7, 9 (5 digits).
We need to form a 6-digit number.
Each of the 6 places can be filled in 5 ways.
Total numbers = $5^6 = 15625$.

questions.question: In a football championship, 153 matches were played. Every two teams played one match with each other. The number of teams, participating in the championship is ______.
questions.solution:
Let $n$ be the number of teams.
Number of matches = ${}^nC_2 = 153$.
$\frac{n(n-1)}{2} = 153 \implies n(n-1) = 306$.
$18 \times 17 = 306$, so $n = 18$.

questions.question: The total number of ways in which six ‘+’ and four ‘–’ signs can be arranged in a line such that no two signs ‘–’ occur together is ______.
questions.solution:
Arrange 6 '+' signs: 1 way (identical).
This creates 7 gaps. We need to place 4 '-' signs in these gaps.
Ways = ${}^7C_4 = \frac{7 \times 6 \times 5 \times 4}{24} = 35$.

questions.question: A committee of 6 is to be chosen from 10 men and 7 women so as to contain atleast 3 men and 2 women. In how many different ways can this be done if two particular women refuse to serve on the same committee.
questions.solution:
Total ways (at least 3M, 2W):
- (3M, 3W): ${}^{10}C_3 \times {}^7C_3 = 120 \times 35 = 4200$.
- (4M, 2W): ${}^{10}C_4 \times {}^7C_2 = 210 \times 21 = 4410$.
Total = 8610.
Subtract cases where 2 particular women (W1, W2) are together:
We need to select 4 more members. W1, W2 are included (so 2W already).
- Need 3M, 1W more: ${}^{10}C_3 \times {}^5C_1 = 120 \times 5 = 600$.
- Need 4M, 0W more: ${}^{10}C_4 \times {}^5C_0 = 210 \times 1 = 210$.
Together ways = $600 + 210 = 810$.
Required ways = $8610 - 810 = 7800$.

questions.question: A box contains 2 white balls, 3 black balls and 4 red balls. The number of ways three balls be drawn from the box if at least one black ball is to be included in the draw is ______.
questions.solution:
Total balls = 9. Draw 3.
Total ways = ${}^9C_3 = 84$.
Ways with no black ball (select from 2W + 4R = 6): ${}^6C_3 = 20$.
Ways with at least one black = $84 - 20 = 64$.

questions.question: There are 12 points in a plane of which 5 points are collinear, then the number of lines obtained by joining these points in pairs is ${}^{12}C_2 - {}^{5}C_2$.
questions.solution: The correct formula is ${}^{12}C_2 - {}^{5}C_2 + 1$. The 5 collinear points form 1 line, which must be added back.

questions.question: Three letters can be posted in five letterboxes in $3^5$ ways.
questions.solution: Each of the 3 letters has 5 options. Total ways = $5 \times 5 \times 5 = 5^3 = 125$.

questions.question: In the permutations of $n$ things, $r$ taken together, the number of permutations in which $m$ particular things occur together is ${}^{n-m}P_{r-m} \times {}^rP_m$.
questions.solution: If $m$ particular things are together, we treat them as one unit. We select $r-m$ other things from $n-m$ in ${}^{n-m}C_{r-m}$ ways. Then arrange $(r-m+1)$ units in $(r-m+1)!$ ways, and the $m$ things internally in $m!$ ways. The given formula is incorrect.

questions.question: In a steamer there are stalls for 12 animals, and there are horses, cows and calves (not less than 12 each) ready to be shipped. They can be loaded in $3^{12}$ ways.
questions.solution: Each of the 12 stalls can be filled by any of the 3 types of animals. Total ways = $3^{12}$.

questions.question: If some or all of $n$ objects are taken at a time, the number of combinations is $2^{n-1}$.
questions.solution: The number of combinations of $n$ objects taken some or all at a time is $2^n - 1$ (excluding the empty set).

questions.question: There will be only 24 selections containing at least one red ball out of a bag containing 4 red and 5 black balls. It is being given that the balls of the same colour are identical.
questions.solution:
Red balls (4 identical): Choose 1, 2, 3, or 4 (4 ways).
Black balls (5 identical): Choose 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5 (6 ways).
Total selections = $4 \times 6 = 24$.

questions.question: Eighteen guests are to be seated, half on each side of a long table. Four particular guests desire to sit on one particular side and three others on other side of the table. The number of ways in which the seating arrangements can be made is $\frac{11!}{5!6!} (9!)(9!)$.
questions.solution:
Total 18. 9 per side. 4 fixed on Side A, 3 fixed on Side B.
Remaining guests = 11. Remaining seats: Side A (5), Side B (6).
Select 5 for Side A from 11: ${}^{11}C_5 = \frac{11!}{5! 6!}$.
Arrange 9 on Side A: $9!$. Arrange 9 on Side B: $9!$.
Total = $\frac{11!}{5! 6!} (9!)(9!)$.

questions.question: A candidate is required to answer 7 questions out of 12 questions which are divided into two groups, each containing 6 questions. He is not permitted to attempt more than 5 questions from either group. He can choose the seven questions in 650 ways.

To fill 12 vacancies there are 25 candidates of which 5 are from scheduled castes. If 3 of the vacancies are reserved for scheduled caste candidates while the rest are open to all, the number of ways in which the selection can be made is ${}^5C_3 \times {}^{20}C_9$.
questions.solution:
Select 3 SC from 5: ${}^5C_3$.
The remaining 9 vacancies are open to all, meaning they can be filled by any of the remaining $25-3=22$ candidates.
Correct ways = ${}^5C_3 \times {}^{22}C_9$.

questions.question:
There are 3 books on Mathematics, 4 on Physics and 5 on English. How many different collections can be made such that each collection consists of :

Column IColumn II
(a) One book of each subject(i) 3968
(b) At least one book of each subject(ii) 60
(c) At least one book of English(iii) 3255

Five boys and five girls form a line. Find the number of ways of making the seating arrangement under the following condition:

Column IColumn II
(a) Boys and girls alternate(i) $5! \times 6!$
(b) No two girls sit together(ii) $10! - 5! 6!$
(c) All the girls sit together(iii) $(5!)^2 + (5!)^2$
(d) All the girls are never together(iv) $2! 5! 5!$
questions.solution:
(a) Boys and girls alternate: There are two cases: the line starts with a boy (BGBG...) or a girl (GBGB...). Each case has $5! \times 5!$ arrangements. Total ways = $2 \times 5! \times 5!$. This matches (iv). Note that (iii) is an equivalent expression.
(b) No two girls sit together: First, arrange the 5 boys in $5!$ ways. This creates 6 gaps (_B_B_B_B_B_). To ensure no two girls are together, place the 5 girls in these 6 gaps. This can be done in ${}^6P_5 = 6!$ ways. Total ways = $5! \times 6!$. This matches (i).
(c) All the girls sit together: Treat the 5 girls as a single unit. Now we arrange 6 items (5 boys + 1 unit of girls), which can be done in $6!$ ways. The 5 girls within their unit can be arranged in $5!$ ways. Total ways = $6! \times 5!$. This also matches (i).
(d) All the girls are never together: This is the total number of arrangements minus the arrangements where all girls are together. Total arrangements = $10!$. Arrangements with girls together = $6! \times 5!$. Required ways = $10! - (6! \times 5!)$. This matches (ii).

questions.question:
There are 10 professors and 20 lecturers out of whom a committee of 2 professors and 3 lecturer is to be formed. Find :

Column IColumn II
(a) In how many ways committee can be formed(i) ${}^{10}C_2 \times {}^{19}C_3$
(b) In how many ways a particular professor is included(ii) ${}^{10}C_2 \times {}^{19}C_2$
(c) In how many ways a particular lecturer is included(iii) ${}^9C_1 \times {}^{20}C_3$
(d) In how many ways a particular lecturer is excluded(iv) ${}^{10}C_2 \times {}^{20}C_3$
questions.solution:
(a) ${}^{10}C_2 \times {}^{20}C_3$. Matches (iv).
(b) ${}^9C_1 \times {}^{20}C_3$. Matches (iii).
(c) ${}^{10}C_2 \times {}^{19}C_2$. Matches (ii).
(d) ${}^{10}C_2 \times {}^{19}C_3$. Matches (i).

questions.question:
Using the digits 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, a number of 4 different digits is formed. Find

Column IColumn II
(a) how many numbers are formed?(i) 840
(b) how many numbers are exactly divisible by 2?(ii) 200
(c) how many numbers are exactly divisible by 25?(iii) 360
(d) how many of these are exactly divisble by 4?(iv) 40
questions.solution:
(a) Total numbers formed using 4 distinct digits from 7 is ${}^7P_4 = 7 \times 6 \times 5 \times 4 = 840$. Matches (i).
(b) Divisible by 2: Last digit must be even (2, 4, 6). 3 choices. Remaining 3 digits from 6: ${}^6P_3$. Total = $3 \times 120 = 360$. Matches (iii).
(c) Divisible by 25: Last two digits must be 25 or 75 (since 0 is not available for 50). 2 cases. Remaining 2 digits from 5: ${}^5P_2$. Total = $2 \times 20 = 40$. Matches (iv).
(d) Divisible by 4: Last two digits must be divisible by 4. Possible pairs from {1..7}: 12, 16, 24, 32, 36, 52, 56, 64, 72, 76 (10 pairs). For each pair, remaining 2 digits from 5: ${}^5P_2 = 20$. Total = $10 \times 20 = 200$. Matches (ii).

questions.question:
How many words (with or without dictionary meaning) can be made from the letters of the word MONDAY, assuming that no letter is repeated, if

Column IColumn II
(a) 4 letters are used at a time(i) 720
(b) All letters are used at a time(ii) 240
(c) All letters are used but the first is a vowel(iii) 360
questions.solution:
(a) ${}^6P_4 = 360$. Matches (iii).
(b) $6! = 720$. Matches (i).
(c) First is O or A (2). Remaining 5! $2 \times 120 = 240$. Matches (ii).
